#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Act at a Dinner Party
#Text=This article will teach you the basic essentials of dinner party etiquette .
#Text=Read on to learn about good table manners that will help you through any formal or semi-formal lunch party or dinner party .
#Text=Here you will find instructions regarding good table manners that will help you through any formal or semi-formal lunch or dinner party .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Unfold your napkin and place it on your knee .
#Text=Use it for occasionally wiping your lips or fingers once seated .
#Text=At the end of dinner , leave the napkin tidily on the place setting .
#Text=Wait your turn for food .

#Text=It is traditional to serve the most senior lady at the table , then the other ladies in descending order of rank ( usually equating to age unless you have royalty staying ) , and lastly the gentlemen .
#Text=Never start eating until the hostess begins to eat , then you may .
#Text=If there are lots of different sets of cutlery beside the plate , start at the outside and work in .
#Text=If in doubt , have a look to see what the other guests are doing/using .
#Text=Hold the knife and fork with the handles in the palm of the hand , forefinger on top , and thumb underneath .
#Text=While eating , rest the knife and fork on either side of the plate between mouthfuls .
#Text=When you have finished eating , place them side by side in the center of the plate .
#Text=Try your food .
#Text=In the event of being presented with a dish which you feel unable to eat , it is polite to at least make some attempt to do so .
#Text=Or at the very least , cut it up a little , and move it around the plate !
#Text=It is quite acceptable to leave some food to one side of your plate if you feel as though you have eaten enough .
#Text=On the other hand , do n’t attempt to leave your plate so clean that it looks as though you have n’t eaten in days !
#Text=Make polite conversation with those guests around you .
#Text=Dinner parties are not just about the food ; they are intended to be a sociable occasion .
#Text=Make a point of thanking the host and hostess for their hospitality before leaving .
#Text=Send a personal note to the host and hostess shortly afterwards thanking them for the pleasurable evening .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If you wish to bring a guest as your partner , always check with the host first .
#Text=If you are the one hosting the party and a guest of yours arrives with an unexpected friend , be polite and courteous with them , and speak with your inconsiderate guest at another time .
#Text=Be punctual – never more than 10 minutes late .
#Text=Desserts may be eaten with both a spoon and fork , or alternatively a fork alone if it is a cake or pastry style sweet .
#Text=Should a lady wish to be excused for the bathroom , it is polite for the gentlemen to stand up as she leaves the table , sit down again , and then stand once more when she returns .
#Text=It is considered polite to take along a small gift for your host and hostess .
#Text=Flowers , chocolates , champagne or wine is always appreciated .
#Text=If you know the host/hostess well enough , ask them if they need something to be brought along to the dinner and absolutely bring it with you .
#Text=Always respond to an invitation within a week of receiving it .
#Text=Good dinner party etiquette sometimes involves a degree of diplomacy when it comes to the host ’s choice of food and wine !
#Text=Even if you feel that you can do better , do n’t ever offer your criticism .
#Text=If you feel unable to pay any compliments , at least remain silent on the subject .
#Text=Forks should not be turned over unless being used for eating peas , sweetcorn kernels , rice or other similar foods .
#Text=The fork should never be transferred to the right hand .
#Text=However , at a casual buffet , or barbecue , it is quite acceptable to eat with just a fork .
#Text=Do n't forget your pleases and thank yous !
#Text=Dress according to the recommended ( if any ) dress code .
#Text=Never attempt to “ out dress ” the hostess !
#Text=Believe it or not , it 's perfectly fine to tip your bowl toward you to get every drop of soup .
#Text=Never blow on hot soup , stir it to cool it down .
#Text=Etiquette experts say that the proper way to fill your spoon with soup it to scoop away from you .
#Text=Try to not talk about touchy topics like politics and sex ; you might make it awkward and make the person uncomfortable .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Picking teeth ( unless toothpicks are provided ) is very nasty and unattractive , even if you think no one is looking or you 've " got it covered " .
#Text=Licking fingers is very unattractive !
#Text=The only exception to the latter is when eating meat or poultry on the bone ( such as chicken legs or ribs ) .
#Text=In which case , a finger bowl should be provided .
#Text=Do n’t ever stretch across the table crossing other guests to reach food , wine or condiments ; instead , ask a guest sitting close to pass the item to you .
#Text=Never talk with your mouth full .
#Text=Loud eating noises such as slurping and burping are very impolite .
#Text=Never embarrass yourself by drinking too much wine .
#Text=Where a different wine is served with each course , it is quite acceptable to not finish each glass .
#Text=It is not generally regarded as good dinner table etiquette to use one ’s bread for dipping into soups or mopping up sauces .
